About this report

Report parameters

Contexts

No contexts were selected, so all contexts were included by default.

Sites

The following sites were included:

  • http://192.168.56.102

(If no sites were selected, all sites were included by default.)

An included site must also be within one of the included contexts for its data to be included in the report.

Risk levels

Included: High, Medium, Low, Informational

Excluded: None

Confidence levels

Included: User Confirmed, High, Medium, Low

Excluded: User Confirmed, High, Medium, Low, False Positive

Alerts

  1. Risk=Medium, Confidence=Medium (12)

    1. http://192.168.56.102 (12)

      1. Vulnerable JS Library (1)
        1. GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/js/jquery.min.js
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2017_A09
          • OWASP_2021_A06
          Alert description

          The identified library jquery, version 1.11.1 is vulnerable.
          Other info

          CVE-2020-11023

          CVE-2020-11022

          CVE-2015-9251

          CVE-2019-11358

          Evidence 
          /*! jQuery v1.11.1
          Solution

          Please upgrade to the latest version of jquery.
      2. X-Frame-Options Header Not Set (11)
        1. GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?name=ZAP&page&pass=ZAP
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • WSTG-v42-CLNT-09
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          X-Frame-Options header is not included in the HTTP response to protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks.
          Request
          Request line and header section (343 bytes) 
          GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?name=ZAP&page&pass=ZAP HTTP/1.1

Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache

          Response
          Status line and header section (330 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK

          Response body (2417 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML>

							</nav>

						<!-- Search -->
							<section class="box search">
								<form method="post" action="index.php?page=search.php">
									<input type="text" class="text" name="search" placeholder="Search" />
								</form>
							</section>

						<!-- Copyright -->
							<ul id="copyright">
							</ul>
					</div>
			</div>
	</body>
</html>
          Parameter 
          X-Frame-Options
          Solution

          Most modern Web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. Alternatively consider implementing Content Security Policy's "frame-ancestors" directive.

</html>
          Parameter 
          X-Frame-Options
          Solution

          Most modern Web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. Alternatively consider implementing Content Security Policy's "frame-ancestors" directive.

		<!--[if lte IE 8]><script src="css/ie/html5shiv.js"></script><![endif]-->
		<script src="js/jquery.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel-layers.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/init.js"></script>
		<noscript>
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/skel.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-desktop.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-wide.css" />
		</noscript>
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><link rel="stylesheet" href="css/ie/v8.css" /><![endif]-->
	</head>
	<!--
		Note: Set the body element's class to "left-sidebar" to position the sidebar on the left.
		Set it to "right-sidebar" to, you guessed it, position it on the right.
	-->
	<body class="left-sidebar">

		<!-- Wrapper -->
			<div id="wrapper">

				<!-- Content -->
					<div id="content">
						<div class="inner">
                            <div style="width:20%;">
        <form method="get" name="login">
        <label>Meno</label>
        <input name="name" value="" type="text" placeholder="LamaCoder" autofocus />
        <label>Heslo</label>
        <input name="pass" value="" type="password" placeholder="********" />
        <br />
        <button class="button" name="logIN" value="1">Prihlasi</button>
    </form>
</div>
						</div>
					</div>

				<!-- Sidebar -->
					<div id="sidebar">
					
						<!-- Logo -->
							<h1 id="logo"><a href="#">LameBlog</a></h1>
					
						<!-- Nav -->
							<nav id="nav">
								<ul>
									<li class="current"><a href="./?page=">lnky</a></li>
                                    <li><a href="./?page=kontakt.php">Kontakt</a></li>
                                    <li><a href="./?page=login.php">Login</a></li>								</ul>
							</nav>

						<!-- Search -->
							<section class="box search">
								<form method="post" action="index.php?page=search.php">
									<input type="text" class="text" name="search" placeholder="Search" />
								</form>
							</section>

						<!-- Copyright -->
							<ul id="copyright">
							</ul>
					</div>
			</div>
	</body>
</html>
          Parameter 
          X-Frame-Options
          Solution

          Most modern Web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. Alternatively consider implementing Content Security Policy's "frame-ancestors" directive.

Alternatively consider implementing Content Security Policy's "frame-ancestors" directive.

          Parameter 
          X-Frame-Options

Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. Alternatively consider implementing Content Security Policy's "frame-ancestors" directive.

  2. Risk=Low, Confidence=Medium (56)

    1. http://192.168.56.102 (56)

      1. Absence of Anti-CSRF Tokens (22)
        1. GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?name=ZAP&page&pass=ZAP
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A01
          • WSTG-v42-SESS-05
          • OWASP_2017_A05
          Alert description

          No Anti-CSRF tokens were found in a HTML submission form.

          A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

          CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

          * The victim has an active session on the target site.

          * The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

          * The victim is on the same local network as the target site.

          CSRF has primarily been used to perform an action against a target site using the victim's privileges, but recent techniques have been discovered to disclose information by gaining access to the response. The risk of information disclosure is dramatically increased when the target site is vulnerable to XSS, because XSS can be used as a platform for CSRF, allowing the attack to operate within the bounds of the same-origin policy.
          Other info

          No known Anti-CSRF token [anticsrf, CSRFToken, __RequestVerificationToken, csrfmiddlewaretoken, authenticity_token, OWASP_CSRFTOKEN, anoncsrf, csrf_token, _csrf, _csrfSecret, __csrf_magic, CSRF, _token, _csrf_token] was found in the following HTML form: [Form 1: "name" "pass" ].
          Request
          Request line and header section (343 bytes) 
          GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?name=ZAP&page&pass=ZAP HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.56.102
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?page
Cookie: PHPSESSID=o2h59f8rui5m7beduecksp1jp7
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (330 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Thu, 02 Dec 2021 17:35:33 GMT
Server: Apache/2.2.22 (Debian)
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.4.39-0+deb7u2
Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT
Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0
Pragma: no-cache
Vary: Accept-Encoding
Content-Length: 2417
Content-Type: text/html
          Response body (2417 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML>
<html>
	<head>
		<title>VulnerableBlog9000</title>
		<meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" />
		<meta name="description" content="" />
		<meta name="keywords" content="" />
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><script src="css/ie/html5shiv.js"></script><![endif]-->
		<script src="js/jquery.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel-layers.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/init.js"></script>
		<noscript>
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/skel.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-desktop.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-wide.css" />
		</noscript>
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><link rel="stylesheet" href="css/ie/v8.css" /><![endif]-->
	</head>
	<!--
		Note: Set the body element's class to "left-sidebar" to position the sidebar on the left.
		Set it to "right-sidebar" to, you guessed it, position it on the right.
	-->
	<body class="left-sidebar">

		<!-- Wrapper -->
			<div id="wrapper">

				<!-- Content -->
					<div id="content">
						<div class="inner">
                            <div style="width:20%;">
        <form method="get" name="login">
        <label>Meno</label>
        <input name="name" value="" type="text" placeholder="LamaCoder" autofocus />
        <label>Heslo</label>
        <input name="pass" value="" type="password" placeholder="********" />
        <br />
        <button class="button" name="logIN" value="1">Prihlasi</button>
    </form>
</div>
						</div>
					</div>

				<!-- Sidebar -->
					<div id="sidebar">
					
						<!-- Logo -->
							<h1 id="logo"><a href="#">LameBlog</a></h1>
					
						<!-- Nav -->
							<nav id="nav">
								<ul>
									<li class="current"><a href="./?page=">lnky</a></li>
                                    <li><a href="./?page=kontakt.php">Kontakt</a></li>
                                    <li><a href="./?page=login.php">Login</a></li>								</ul>
							</nav>

						<!-- Search -->
							<section class="box search">
								<form method="post" action="index.php?page=search.php">
									<input type="text" class="text" name="search" placeholder="Search" />
								</form>
							</section>

						<!-- Copyright -->
							<ul id="copyright">
							</ul>
					</div>
			</div>
	</body>
</html>
          Evidence 
          <form method="get" name="login">
          Solution

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.

          For example, use anti-CSRF packages such as the OWASP CSRFGuard.

          Phase: Implementation

          Ensure that your application is free of cross-site scripting issues, because most CSRF defenses can be bypassed using attacker-controlled script.

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Generate a unique nonce for each form, place the nonce into the form, and verify the nonce upon receipt of the form. Be sure that the nonce is not predictable (CWE-330).

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Identify especially dangerous operations. When the user performs a dangerous operation, send a separate confirmation request to ensure that the user intended to perform that operation.

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Use the ESAPI Session Management control.

          This control includes a component for CSRF.

          Do not use the GET method for any request that triggers a state change.

          Phase: Implementation

          Check the HTTP Referer header to see if the request originated from an expected page. This could break legitimate functionality, because users or proxies may have disabled sending the Referer for privacy reasons.
        2. GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?name=ZAP&page&pass=ZAP
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A01
          • WSTG-v42-SESS-05
          • OWASP_2017_A05
          Alert description

          No Anti-CSRF tokens were found in a HTML submission form.

          A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

          CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

          * The victim has an active session on the target site.

          * The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

          * The victim is on the same local network as the target site.

          CSRF has primarily been used to perform an action against a target site using the victim's privileges, but recent techniques have been discovered to disclose information by gaining access to the response. The risk of information disclosure is dramatically increased when the target site is vulnerable to XSS, because XSS can be used as a platform for CSRF, allowing the attack to operate within the bounds of the same-origin policy.
          Other info

          No known Anti-CSRF token [anticsrf, CSRFToken, __RequestVerificationToken, csrfmiddlewaretoken, authenticity_token, OWASP_CSRFTOKEN, anoncsrf, csrf_token, _csrf, _csrfSecret, __csrf_magic, CSRF, _token, _csrf_token] was found in the following HTML form: [Form 2: "search" ].
          Request
          Request line and header section (343 bytes) 
          GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?name=ZAP&page&pass=ZAP HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.56.102
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?page
Cookie: PHPSESSID=o2h59f8rui5m7beduecksp1jp7
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (330 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Thu, 02 Dec 2021 17:35:33 GMT
Server: Apache/2.2.22 (Debian)
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.4.39-0+deb7u2
Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT
Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0
Pragma: no-cache
Vary: Accept-Encoding
Content-Length: 2417
Content-Type: text/html
          Response body (2417 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML>
<html>
	<head>
		<title>VulnerableBlog9000</title>

		<meta name="keywords" content="" />
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><script src="css/ie/html5shiv.js"></script><![endif]-->
		<script src="js/jquery.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel-layers.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/init.js"></script>
		<noscript>
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/skel.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-desktop.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-wide.css" />
		</noscript>
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><link rel="stylesheet" href="css/ie/v8.css" /><![endif]-->
	</head>
	<!--
		Note: Set the body element's class to "left-sidebar" to position the sidebar on the left.
		Set it to "right-sidebar" to, you guessed it, position it on the right.
	-->
	<body class="left-sidebar">

		<!-- Wrapper -->
			<div id="wrapper">

				<!-- Content -->
					<div id="content">
						<div class="inner">
                            <div style="width:20%;">
        <form method="get" name="login">
        <label>Meno</label>
        <input name="name" value="" type="text" placeholder="LamaCoder" autofocus />
        <label>Heslo</label>
        <input name="pass" value="" type="password" placeholder="********" />
        <br />

    </form>

                                    <li><a href="./?page=kontakt.php">Kontakt</a></li>
                                    <li><a href="./?page=login.php">Login</a></li>								</ul>
							</nav>

						<!-- Search -->
							<section class="box search">
								<form method="post" action="index.php?page=search.php">
									<input type="text" class="text" name="search" placeholder="Search" />

          Evidence 
          <form method="post" action="index.php?page=search.php">
          Solution

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.

          For example, use anti-CSRF packages such as the OWASP CSRFGuard.

          Phase: Implementation

          Ensure that your application is free of cross-site scripting issues, because most CSRF defenses can be bypassed using attacker-controlled script.

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Generate a unique nonce for each form, place the nonce into the form, and verify the nonce upon receipt of the form. Be sure that the nonce is not predictable (CWE-330).

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Identify especially dangerous operations. When the user performs a dangerous operation, send a separate confirmation request to ensure that the user intended to perform that operation.

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Use the ESAPI Session Management control.

          This control includes a component for CSRF.

          Do not use the GET method for any request that triggers a state change.

          Phase: Implementation

          Check the HTTP Referer header to see if the request originated from an expected page. This could break legitimate functionality, because users or proxies may have disabled sending the Referer for privacy reasons.

Pragma: no-cache
Vary: Accept-Encoding
Content-Length: 2417
Content-Type: text/html
          Response body (2417 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML>
<html>
	<head>
		<title>VulnerableBlog9000</title>
		<meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" />
		<meta name="description" content="" />
		<meta name="keywords" content="" />
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><script src="css/ie/html5shiv.js"></script><![endif]-->
		<script src="js/jquery.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel-layers.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/init.js"></script>
		<noscript>
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/skel.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-desktop.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-wide.css" />
		</noscript>
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><link rel="stylesheet" href="css/ie/v8.css" /><![endif]-->
	</head>
	<!--
		Note: Set the body element's class to "left-sidebar" to position the sidebar on the left.
		Set it to "right-sidebar" to, you guessed it, position it on the right.
	-->
	<body class="left-sidebar">

		<!-- Wrapper -->
			<div id="wrapper">

				<!-- Content -->
					<div id="content">
						<div class="inner">
                            <div style="width:20%;">
        <form method="get" name="login">
        <label>Meno</label>
        <input name="name" value="" type="text" placeholder="LamaCoder" autofocus />
        <label>Heslo</label>
        <input name="pass" value="" type="password" placeholder="********" />
        <br />
        <button class="button" name="logIN" value="1">Prihlasi</button>
    </form>
</div>
						</div>
					</div>

				<!-- Sidebar -->
					<div id="sidebar">
					
						<!-- Logo -->
							<h1 id="logo"><a href="#">LameBlog</a></h1>
					
						<!-- Nav -->
							<nav id="nav">
								<ul>
									<li class="current"><a href="./?page=">lnky</a></li>
                                    <li><a href="./?page=kontakt.php">Kontakt</a></li>
                                    <li><a href="./?page=login.php">Login</a></li>								</ul>
							</nav>

						<!-- Search -->
							<section class="box search">
								<form method="post" action="index.php?page=search.php">
									<input type="text" class="text" name="search" placeholder="Search" />
								</form>
							</section>

						<!-- Copyright -->
							<ul id="copyright">
							</ul>
					</div>
			</div>
	</body>
</html>
          Evidence 
          <form method="get" name="login">
          Solution

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.

          For example, use anti-CSRF packages such as the OWASP CSRFGuard.

          Phase: Implementation

          Ensure that your application is free of cross-site scripting issues, because most CSRF defenses can be bypassed using attacker-controlled script.

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Generate a unique nonce for each form, place the nonce into the form, and verify the nonce upon receipt of the form. Be sure that the nonce is not predictable (CWE-330).

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Identify especially dangerous operations. When the user performs a dangerous operation, send a separate confirmation request to ensure that the user intended to perform that operation.

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Use the ESAPI Session Management control.

          This control includes a component for CSRF.

          Do not use the GET method for any request that triggers a state change.

          Phase: Implementation

          Check the HTTP Referer header to see if the request originated from an expected page. This could break legitimate functionality, because users or proxies may have disabled sending the Referer for privacy reasons.
        6. GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?name=ZAP&page=login.php&pass=ZAP
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A01
          • WSTG-v42-SESS-05
          • OWASP_2017_A05
          Alert description

          No Anti-CSRF tokens were found in a HTML submission form.

          A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

          CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

          * The victim has an active session on the target site.

          * The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

          * The victim is on the same local network as the target site.

          CSRF has primarily been used to perform an action against a target site using the victim's privileges, but recent techniques have been discovered to disclose information by gaining access to the response. The risk of information disclosure is dramatically increased when the target site is vulnerable to XSS, because XSS can be used as a platform for CSRF, allowing the attack to operate within the bounds of the same-origin policy.
          Other info

          No known Anti-CSRF token [anticsrf, CSRFToken, __RequestVerificationToken, csrfmiddlewaretoken, authenticity_token, OWASP_CSRFTOKEN, anoncsrf, csrf_token, _csrf, _csrfSecret, __csrf_magic, CSRF, _token, _csrf_token] was found in the following HTML form: [Form 2: "search" ].
          Request
          Request line and header section (363 bytes) 
          GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?name=ZAP&page=login.php&pass=ZAP HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.56.102
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?page=login.php
Cookie: PHPSESSID=o2h59f8rui5m7beduecksp1jp7
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (330 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Thu, 02 Dec 2021 17:35:33 GMT
Server: Apache/2.2.22 (Debian)
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.4.39-0+deb7u2
Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT
Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0
Pragma: no-cache
Vary: Accept-Encoding
Content-Length: 2417
Content-Type: text/html
          Response body (2417 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML>
<html>
	<head>

		<meta name="description" content="" />
		<meta name="keywords" content="" />

		<noscript>

			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-desktop.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-wide.css" />
		</noscript>
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><link rel="stylesheet" href="css/ie/v8.css" /><![endif]-->
	</head>
	<!--
		Note: Set the body element's class to "left-sidebar" to position the sidebar on the left.
		Set it to "right-sidebar" to, you guessed it, position it on the right.
	-->
	<body class="left-sidebar">

				<!-- Content -->

        <br />
        <button class="button" name="logIN" value="1">Prihlasi</button>

                                    <li><a href="./?page=login.php">Login</a></li>								</ul>

          Evidence 
          <form method="post" action="index.php?page=search.php">
          Solution

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.

          For example, use anti-CSRF packages such as the OWASP CSRFGuard.

          Phase: Implementation

          Ensure that your application is free of cross-site scripting issues, because most CSRF defenses can be bypassed using attacker-controlled script.

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Generate a unique nonce for each form, place the nonce into the form, and verify the nonce upon receipt of the form. Be sure that the nonce is not predictable (CWE-330).

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Identify especially dangerous operations. When the user performs a dangerous operation, send a separate confirmation request to ensure that the user intended to perform that operation.

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Use the ESAPI Session Management control.

          This control includes a component for CSRF.

          Do not use the GET method for any request that triggers a state change.

          Phase: Implementation

          Check the HTTP Referer header to see if the request originated from an expected page. This could break legitimate functionality, because users or proxies may have disabled sending the Referer for privacy reasons.

          • WSTG-v42-SESS-05
          • OWASP_2017_A05

          CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

          * The victim has an active session on the target site.

          * The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

          * The victim is on the same local network as the target site.

          GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?page=kontakt.php HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.56.102
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/index.php
Cookie: PHPSESSID=o2h59f8rui5m7beduecksp1jp7
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (330 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Thu, 02 Dec 2021 17:35:33 GMT
Server: Apache/2.2.22 (Debian)
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.4.39-0+deb7u2
Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT
Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0
Pragma: no-cache
Vary: Accept-Encoding
Content-Length: 2417
Content-Type: text/html
          Response body (2417 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML>
<html>
	<head>
		<title>VulnerableBlog9000</title>
		<meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" />
		<meta name="description" content="" />
		<meta name="keywords" content="" />
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><script src="css/ie/html5shiv.js"></script><![endif]-->
		<script src="js/jquery.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel-layers.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/init.js"></script>
		<noscript>
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/skel.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-desktop.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-wide.css" />
		</noscript>
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><link rel="stylesheet" href="css/ie/v8.css" /><![endif]-->
	</head>
	<!--
		Note: Set the body element's class to "left-sidebar" to position the sidebar on the left.
		Set it to "right-sidebar" to, you guessed it, position it on the right.
	-->
	<body class="left-sidebar">

		<!-- Wrapper -->
			<div id="wrapper">

				<!-- Content -->
					<div id="content">
						<div class="inner">
                            <div style="width:20%;">
        <form method="get" name="login">
        <label>Meno</label>
        <input name="name" value="" type="text" placeholder="LamaCoder" autofocus />
        <label>Heslo</label>
        <input name="pass" value="" type="password" placeholder="********" />
        <br />
        <button class="button" name="logIN" value="1">Prihlasi</button>
    </form>
</div>
						</div>
					</div>

				<!-- Sidebar -->
					<div id="sidebar">
					
						<!-- Logo -->
							<h1 id="logo"><a href="#">LameBlog</a></h1>
					
						<!-- Nav -->
							<nav id="nav">
								<ul>
									<li class="current"><a href="./?page=">lnky</a></li>
                                    <li><a href="./?page=kontakt.php">Kontakt</a></li>
                                    <li><a href="./?page=login.php">Login</a></li>								</ul>
							</nav>

						<!-- Search -->
							<section class="box search">
								<form method="post" action="index.php?page=search.php">
									<input type="text" class="text" name="search" placeholder="Search" />
								</form>
							</section>

						<!-- Copyright -->
							<ul id="copyright">
							</ul>
					</div>
			</div>
	</body>
</html>
          Evidence 
          <form method="get" name="login">
          Solution

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.

          For example, use anti-CSRF packages such as the OWASP CSRFGuard.

          Phase: Implementation

          Ensure that your application is free of cross-site scripting issues, because most CSRF defenses can be bypassed using attacker-controlled script.

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Generate a unique nonce for each form, place the nonce into the form, and verify the nonce upon receipt of the form. Be sure that the nonce is not predictable (CWE-330).

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Identify especially dangerous operations. When the user performs a dangerous operation, send a separate confirmation request to ensure that the user intended to perform that operation.

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Use the ESAPI Session Management control.

          This control includes a component for CSRF.

          Do not use the GET method for any request that triggers a state change.

          Phase: Implementation

          Check the HTTP Referer header to see if the request originated from an expected page. This could break legitimate functionality, because users or proxies may have disabled sending the Referer for privacy reasons.
        10. GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?page=kontakt.php
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A01
          • WSTG-v42-SESS-05
          • OWASP_2017_A05
          Alert description

          No Anti-CSRF tokens were found in a HTML submission form.

          A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

          CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

          * The victim has an active session on the target site.

          * The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

          * The victim is on the same local network as the target site.

          CSRF has primarily been used to perform an action against a target site using the victim's privileges, but recent techniques have been discovered to disclose information by gaining access to the response. The risk of information disclosure is dramatically increased when the target site is vulnerable to XSS, because XSS can be used as a platform for CSRF, allowing the attack to operate within the bounds of the same-origin policy.
          Other info

          No known Anti-CSRF token [anticsrf, CSRFToken, __RequestVerificationToken, csrfmiddlewaretoken, authenticity_token, OWASP_CSRFTOKEN, anoncsrf, csrf_token, _csrf, _csrfSecret, __csrf_magic, CSRF, _token, _csrf_token] was found in the following HTML form: [Form 2: "search" ].
          Request
          Request line and header section (341 bytes) 
          GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?page=kontakt.php HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.56.102
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/index.php
Cookie: PHPSESSID=o2h59f8rui5m7beduecksp1jp7
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (330 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK

Server: Apache/2.2.22 (Debian)
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.4.39-0+deb7u2
Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT
Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0
Pragma: no-cache
Vary: Accept-Encoding
Content-Length: 2417
Content-Type: text/html
          Response body (2417 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML>

		</noscript>

          Evidence

          Solution

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.

          For example, use anti-CSRF packages such as the OWASP CSRFGuard.

          Phase: Implementation

          Ensure that your application is free of cross-site scripting issues, because most CSRF defenses can be bypassed using attacker-controlled script.

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Generate a unique nonce for each form, place the nonce into the form, and verify the nonce upon receipt of the form. Be sure that the nonce is not predictable (CWE-330).

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Identify especially dangerous operations. When the user performs a dangerous operation, send a separate confirmation request to ensure that the user intended to perform that operation.

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Use the ESAPI Session Management control.

          This control includes a component for CSRF.

          Do not use the GET method for any request that triggers a state change.

          Phase: Implementation

          Check the HTTP Referer header to see if the request originated from an expected page. This could break legitimate functionality, because users or proxies may have disabled sending the Referer for privacy reasons.

        13. GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/index.php
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A01
          • WSTG-v42-SESS-05
          • OWASP_2017_A05
          Alert description

          No Anti-CSRF tokens were found in a HTML submission form.

          A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

          CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

          * The victim has an active session on the target site.

          * The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

          * The victim is on the same local network as the target site.

          CSRF has primarily been used to perform an action against a target site using the victim's privileges, but recent techniques have been discovered to disclose information by gaining access to the response. The risk of information disclosure is dramatically increased when the target site is vulnerable to XSS, because XSS can be used as a platform for CSRF, allowing the attack to operate within the bounds of the same-origin policy.
          Other info

          No known Anti-CSRF token [anticsrf, CSRFToken, __RequestVerificationToken, csrfmiddlewaretoken, authenticity_token, OWASP_CSRFTOKEN, anoncsrf, csrf_token, _csrf, _csrfSecret, __csrf_magic, CSRF, _token, _csrf_token] was found in the following HTML form: [Form 1: "name" "pass" ].
          Request
          Request line and header section (225 bytes) 
          GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/index.php HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.56.102
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (388 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Thu, 02 Dec 2021 17:35:33 GMT
Server: Apache/2.2.22 (Debian)
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.4.39-0+deb7u2
Set-Cookie: PHPSESSID=nik57maeaafc0mieff1k8otd07; path=/
Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT
Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0
Pragma: no-cache
Vary: Accept-Encoding
Content-Length: 2417
Content-Type: text/html
          Response body (2417 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML>
<html>
	<head>
		<title>VulnerableBlog9000</title>
		<meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" />
		<meta name="description" content="" />
		<meta name="keywords" content="" />
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><script src="css/ie/html5shiv.js"></script><![endif]-->
		<script src="js/jquery.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel-layers.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/init.js"></script>
		<noscript>
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/skel.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-desktop.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-wide.css" />
		</noscript>
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><link rel="stylesheet" href="css/ie/v8.css" /><![endif]-->
	</head>
	<!--
		Note: Set the body element's class to "left-sidebar" to position the sidebar on the left.
		Set it to "right-sidebar" to, you guessed it, position it on the right.
	-->
	<body class="left-sidebar">

		<!-- Wrapper -->
			<div id="wrapper">

				<!-- Content -->
					<div id="content">
						<div class="inner">
                            <div style="width:20%;">
        <form method="get" name="login">
        <label>Meno</label>
        <input name="name" value="" type="text" placeholder="LamaCoder" autofocus />
        <label>Heslo</label>
        <input name="pass" value="" type="password" placeholder="********" />
        <br />
        <button class="button" name="logIN" value="1">Prihlasi</button>
    </form>
</div>
						</div>
					</div>

				<!-- Sidebar -->
					<div id="sidebar">
					
						<!-- Logo -->
							<h1 id="logo"><a href="#">LameBlog</a></h1>
					
						<!-- Nav -->
							<nav id="nav">
								<ul>
									<li class="current"><a href="./?page=">lnky</a></li>
                                    <li><a href="./?page=kontakt.php">Kontakt</a></li>
                                    <li><a href="./?page=login.php">Login</a></li>								</ul>
							</nav>

						<!-- Search -->
							<section class="box search">
								<form method="post" action="index.php?page=search.php">
									<input type="text" class="text" name="search" placeholder="Search" />
								</form>
							</section>

						<!-- Copyright -->
							<ul id="copyright">
							</ul>
					</div>
			</div>
	</body>
</html>
          Evidence 
          <form method="get" name="login">
          Solution

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.

          For example, use anti-CSRF packages such as the OWASP CSRFGuard.

          Phase: Implementation

          Ensure that your application is free of cross-site scripting issues, because most CSRF defenses can be bypassed using attacker-controlled script.

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Generate a unique nonce for each form, place the nonce into the form, and verify the nonce upon receipt of the form. Be sure that the nonce is not predictable (CWE-330).

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Identify especially dangerous operations. When the user performs a dangerous operation, send a separate confirmation request to ensure that the user intended to perform that operation.

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Use the ESAPI Session Management control.

          This control includes a component for CSRF.

          Do not use the GET method for any request that triggers a state change.

          Phase: Implementation

          Check the HTTP Referer header to see if the request originated from an expected page. This could break legitimate functionality, because users or proxies may have disabled sending the Referer for privacy reasons.
        14. GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/index.php
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A01
          • WSTG-v42-SESS-05
          • OWASP_2017_A05
          Alert description

          No Anti-CSRF tokens were found in a HTML submission form.

          A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

          CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

          * The victim has an active session on the target site.

          * The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

          * The victim is on the same local network as the target site.

          CSRF has primarily been used to perform an action against a target site using the victim's privileges, but recent techniques have been discovered to disclose information by gaining access to the response. The risk of information disclosure is dramatically increased when the target site is vulnerable to XSS, because XSS can be used as a platform for CSRF, allowing the attack to operate within the bounds of the same-origin policy.
          Other info

          No known Anti-CSRF token [anticsrf, CSRFToken, __RequestVerificationToken, csrfmiddlewaretoken, authenticity_token, OWASP_CSRFTOKEN, anoncsrf, csrf_token, _csrf, _csrfSecret, __csrf_magic, CSRF, _token, _csrf_token] was found in the following HTML form: [Form 2: "search" ].
          Request
          Request line and header section (225 bytes) 
          GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/index.php HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.56.102
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache

          Response
          Status line and header section (388 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK

Set-Cookie: PHPSESSID=nik57maeaafc0mieff1k8otd07; path=/
Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT
Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0
Pragma: no-cache
Vary: Accept-Encoding
Content-Length: 2417

          Response body (2417 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML>

          Solution

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.

          For example, use anti-CSRF packages such as the OWASP CSRFGuard.

          Phase: Implementation

          Ensure that your application is free of cross-site scripting issues, because most CSRF defenses can be bypassed using attacker-controlled script.

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Generate a unique nonce for each form, place the nonce into the form, and verify the nonce upon receipt of the form. Be sure that the nonce is not predictable (CWE-330).

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Identify especially dangerous operations. When the user performs a dangerous operation, send a separate confirmation request to ensure that the user intended to perform that operation.

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Use the ESAPI Session Management control.

          This control includes a component for CSRF.

          Do not use the GET method for any request that triggers a state change.

          Phase: Implementation

          Check the HTTP Referer header to see if the request originated from an expected page. This could break legitimate functionality, because users or proxies may have disabled sending the Referer for privacy reasons.

          • WSTG-v42-SESS-05

          No Anti-CSRF tokens were found in a HTML submission form.

          A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

          CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

          * The victim has an active session on the target site.

          * The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A01
          • WSTG-v42-SESS-05
          • OWASP_2017_A05
          Alert description

          No Anti-CSRF tokens were found in a HTML submission form.

          A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

          CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

          * The victim has an active session on the target site.

          * The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

          * The victim is on the same local network as the target site.

          CSRF has primarily been used to perform an action against a target site using the victim's privileges, but recent techniques have been discovered to disclose information by gaining access to the response. The risk of information disclosure is dramatically increased when the target site is vulnerable to XSS, because XSS can be used as a platform for CSRF, allowing the attack to operate within the bounds of the same-origin policy.
          Other info

          No known Anti-CSRF token [anticsrf, CSRFToken, __RequestVerificationToken, csrfmiddlewaretoken, authenticity_token, OWASP_CSRFTOKEN, anoncsrf, csrf_token, _csrf, _csrfSecret, __csrf_magic, CSRF, _token, _csrf_token] was found in the following HTML form: [Form 1: "name" "pass" ].
          Request
          Request line and header section (351 bytes) 
          GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/index.php?name=ZAP&pass=ZAP HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.56.102
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/index.php
Cookie: PHPSESSID=o2h59f8rui5m7beduecksp1jp7
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (330 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Thu, 02 Dec 2021 17:35:33 GMT
Server: Apache/2.2.22 (Debian)
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.4.39-0+deb7u2
Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT
Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0
Pragma: no-cache
Vary: Accept-Encoding
Content-Length: 2417
Content-Type: text/html
          Response body (2417 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML>
<html>
	<head>
		<title>VulnerableBlog9000</title>
		<meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" />
		<meta name="description" content="" />
		<meta name="keywords" content="" />
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><script src="css/ie/html5shiv.js"></script><![endif]-->
		<script src="js/jquery.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel-layers.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/init.js"></script>
		<noscript>
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/skel.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-desktop.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-wide.css" />
		</noscript>
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><link rel="stylesheet" href="css/ie/v8.css" /><![endif]-->
	</head>
	<!--
		Note: Set the body element's class to "left-sidebar" to position the sidebar on the left.
		Set it to "right-sidebar" to, you guessed it, position it on the right.
	-->
	<body class="left-sidebar">

		<!-- Wrapper -->
			<div id="wrapper">

				<!-- Content -->
					<div id="content">
						<div class="inner">
                            <div style="width:20%;">
        <form method="get" name="login">
        <label>Meno</label>
        <input name="name" value="" type="text" placeholder="LamaCoder" autofocus />
        <label>Heslo</label>
        <input name="pass" value="" type="password" placeholder="********" />
        <br />
        <button class="button" name="logIN" value="1">Prihlasi</button>
    </form>
</div>
						</div>
					</div>

				<!-- Sidebar -->
					<div id="sidebar">
					
						<!-- Logo -->
							<h1 id="logo"><a href="#">LameBlog</a></h1>
					
						<!-- Nav -->
							<nav id="nav">
								<ul>
									<li class="current"><a href="./?page=">lnky</a></li>
                                    <li><a href="./?page=kontakt.php">Kontakt</a></li>
                                    <li><a href="./?page=login.php">Login</a></li>								</ul>
							</nav>

						<!-- Search -->
							<section class="box search">
								<form method="post" action="index.php?page=search.php">
									<input type="text" class="text" name="search" placeholder="Search" />
								</form>
							</section>

						<!-- Copyright -->
							<ul id="copyright">
							</ul>
					</div>
			</div>
	</body>
</html>
          Evidence 
          <form method="get" name="login">
          Solution

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.

          For example, use anti-CSRF packages such as the OWASP CSRFGuard.

          Phase: Implementation

          Ensure that your application is free of cross-site scripting issues, because most CSRF defenses can be bypassed using attacker-controlled script.

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Generate a unique nonce for each form, place the nonce into the form, and verify the nonce upon receipt of the form. Be sure that the nonce is not predictable (CWE-330).

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Identify especially dangerous operations. When the user performs a dangerous operation, send a separate confirmation request to ensure that the user intended to perform that operation.

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Use the ESAPI Session Management control.

          This control includes a component for CSRF.

          Do not use the GET method for any request that triggers a state change.

          Phase: Implementation

          Check the HTTP Referer header to see if the request originated from an expected page. This could break legitimate functionality, because users or proxies may have disabled sending the Referer for privacy reasons.
        18. GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/index.php?name=ZAP&pass=ZAP
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A01
          • WSTG-v42-SESS-05
          • OWASP_2017_A05
          Alert description

          No Anti-CSRF tokens were found in a HTML submission form.

          A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

          CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

          * The victim has an active session on the target site.

          * The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

          * The victim is on the same local network as the target site.

          CSRF has primarily been used to perform an action against a target site using the victim's privileges, but recent techniques have been discovered to disclose information by gaining access to the response. The risk of information disclosure is dramatically increased when the target site is vulnerable to XSS, because XSS can be used as a platform for CSRF, allowing the attack to operate within the bounds of the same-origin policy.

          Solution

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.

          For example, use anti-CSRF packages such as the OWASP CSRFGuard.

          Phase: Implementation

          Ensure that your application is free of cross-site scripting issues, because most CSRF defenses can be bypassed using attacker-controlled script.

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Generate a unique nonce for each form, place the nonce into the form, and verify the nonce upon receipt of the form. Be sure that the nonce is not predictable (CWE-330).

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Identify especially dangerous operations. When the user performs a dangerous operation, send a separate confirmation request to ensure that the user intended to perform that operation.

          Use the ESAPI Session Management control.

          This control includes a component for CSRF.

          Do not use the GET method for any request that triggers a state change.

          Phase: Implementation

          Check the HTTP Referer header to see if the request originated from an expected page. This could break legitimate functionality, because users or proxies may have disabled sending the Referer for privacy reasons.

          Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.

          For example, use anti-CSRF packages such as the OWASP CSRFGuard.

          Phase: Implementation

          Ensure that your application is free of cross-site scripting issues, because most CSRF defenses can be bypassed using attacker-controlled script.

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Generate a unique nonce for each form, place the nonce into the form, and verify the nonce upon receipt of the form. Be sure that the nonce is not predictable (CWE-330).

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Identify especially dangerous operations. When the user performs a dangerous operation, send a separate confirmation request to ensure that the user intended to perform that operation.

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Use the ESAPI Session Management control.

          This control includes a component for CSRF.

          Do not use the GET method for any request that triggers a state change.

          Phase: Implementation

          Check the HTTP Referer header to see if the request originated from an expected page. This could break legitimate functionality, because users or proxies may have disabled sending the Referer for privacy reasons.
        21. POST http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/index.php?page=search.php
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A01
          • WSTG-v42-SESS-05
          • OWASP_2017_A05
          Alert description

          No Anti-CSRF tokens were found in a HTML submission form.

          A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

          CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

          * The victim has an active session on the target site.

          * The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

          * The victim is on the same local network as the target site.

          CSRF has primarily been used to perform an action against a target site using the victim's privileges, but recent techniques have been discovered to disclose information by gaining access to the response. The risk of information disclosure is dramatically increased when the target site is vulnerable to XSS, because XSS can be used as a platform for CSRF, allowing the attack to operate within the bounds of the same-origin policy.
          Other info

          No known Anti-CSRF token [anticsrf, CSRFToken, __RequestVerificationToken, csrfmiddlewaretoken, authenticity_token, OWASP_CSRFTOKEN, anoncsrf, csrf_token, _csrf, _csrfSecret, __csrf_magic, CSRF, _token, _csrf_token] was found in the following HTML form: [Form 1: "name" "pass" ].
          Request
          Request line and header section (415 bytes) 
          POST http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/index.php?page=search.php HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.56.102
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Referer: http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?page
Content-Length: 10
Cookie: PHPSESSID=o2h59f8rui5m7beduecksp1jp7
          Request body (10 bytes) 
          search=ZAP
          Response
          Status line and header section (330 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Thu, 02 Dec 2021 17:35:33 GMT
Server: Apache/2.2.22 (Debian)
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.4.39-0+deb7u2
Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT
Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0
Pragma: no-cache
Vary: Accept-Encoding
Content-Length: 2417
Content-Type: text/html
          Response body (2417 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML>
<html>
	<head>
		<title>VulnerableBlog9000</title>
		<meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" />
		<meta name="description" content="" />
		<meta name="keywords" content="" />
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><script src="css/ie/html5shiv.js"></script><![endif]-->
		<script src="js/jquery.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel-layers.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/init.js"></script>
		<noscript>
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/skel.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-desktop.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-wide.css" />
		</noscript>
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><link rel="stylesheet" href="css/ie/v8.css" /><![endif]-->
	</head>
	<!--
		Note: Set the body element's class to "left-sidebar" to position the sidebar on the left.
		Set it to "right-sidebar" to, you guessed it, position it on the right.
	-->
	<body class="left-sidebar">

		<!-- Wrapper -->
			<div id="wrapper">

				<!-- Content -->
					<div id="content">
						<div class="inner">
                            <div style="width:20%;">
        <form method="get" name="login">
        <label>Meno</label>
        <input name="name" value="" type="text" placeholder="LamaCoder" autofocus />
        <label>Heslo</label>
        <input name="pass" value="" type="password" placeholder="********" />
        <br />
        <button class="button" name="logIN" value="1">Prihlasi</button>
    </form>
</div>
						</div>
					</div>

				<!-- Sidebar -->
					<div id="sidebar">
					
						<!-- Logo -->
							<h1 id="logo"><a href="#">LameBlog</a></h1>
					
						<!-- Nav -->
							<nav id="nav">
								<ul>
									<li class="current"><a href="./?page=">lnky</a></li>
                                    <li><a href="./?page=kontakt.php">Kontakt</a></li>
                                    <li><a href="./?page=login.php">Login</a></li>								</ul>
							</nav>

						<!-- Search -->
							<section class="box search">
								<form method="post" action="index.php?page=search.php">
									<input type="text" class="text" name="search" placeholder="Search" />
								</form>
							</section>

						<!-- Copyright -->
							<ul id="copyright">
							</ul>
					</div>
			</div>
	</body>
</html>
          Evidence 
          <form method="get" name="login">
          Solution

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.

          For example, use anti-CSRF packages such as the OWASP CSRFGuard.

          Phase: Implementation

          Ensure that your application is free of cross-site scripting issues, because most CSRF defenses can be bypassed using attacker-controlled script.

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Generate a unique nonce for each form, place the nonce into the form, and verify the nonce upon receipt of the form. Be sure that the nonce is not predictable (CWE-330).

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Identify especially dangerous operations. When the user performs a dangerous operation, send a separate confirmation request to ensure that the user intended to perform that operation.

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Use the ESAPI Session Management control.

          This control includes a component for CSRF.

          Do not use the GET method for any request that triggers a state change.

          Phase: Implementation

          Check the HTTP Referer header to see if the request originated from an expected page. This could break legitimate functionality, because users or proxies may have disabled sending the Referer for privacy reasons.
        22. POST http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/index.php?page=search.php
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A01
          • WSTG-v42-SESS-05
          • OWASP_2017_A05
          Alert description

          No Anti-CSRF tokens were found in a HTML submission form.

          A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

          CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

          * The victim has an active session on the target site.

          * The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

          * The victim is on the same local network as the target site.

          CSRF has primarily been used to perform an action against a target site using the victim's privileges, but recent techniques have been discovered to disclose information by gaining access to the response. The risk of information disclosure is dramatically increased when the target site is vulnerable to XSS, because XSS can be used as a platform for CSRF, allowing the attack to operate within the bounds of the same-origin policy.

          Phase: Implementation

          Check the HTTP Referer header to see if the request originated from an expected page. This could break legitimate functionality, because users or proxies may have disabled sending the Referer for privacy reasons.
      2. Cookie No HttpOnly Flag (1)
        1. GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/index.php
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • WSTG-v42-SESS-02
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
          Request
          Request line and header section (225 bytes) 
          GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/index.php HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.56.102
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (388 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK

Set-Cookie: PHPSESSID=nik57maeaafc0mieff1k8otd07; path=/
Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT
Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Vary: Accept-Encoding

      3. Cookie without SameSite Attribute (1)
        1. GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/index.php
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A01
          • WSTG-v42-SESS-02
          • OWASP_2017_A05
          Alert description

          A cookie has been set without the SameSite attribute, which means that the cookie can be sent as a result of a 'cross-site' request. The SameSite attribute is an effective counter measure to cross-site request forgery, cross-site script inclusion, and timing attacks.
          Request
          Request line and header section (225 bytes) 
          GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/index.php HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.56.102
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0

          Parameter 
          PHPSESSID
          Evidence 
          Set-Cookie: PHPSESSID
          Solution

          Ensure that the SameSite attribute is set to either 'lax' or ideally 'strict' for all cookies.
      4. Server Leaks Information via "X-Powered-By" HTTP Response Header Field(s) (11)
        1. GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?name=ZAP&page&pass=ZAP
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A01
          • WSTG-v42-INFO-08
          • OWASP_2017_A03
          Alert description

          The web/application server is leaking information via one or more "X-Powered-By" HTTP response headers. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other frameworks/components your web application is reliant upon and the vulnerabilities such components may be subject to.
          Request
          Request line and header section (343 bytes) 
          GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?name=ZAP&page&pass=ZAP HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.56.102
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?page
Cookie: PHPSESSID=o2h59f8rui5m7beduecksp1jp7
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (330 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK

Server: Apache/2.2.22 (Debian)

Content-Type: text/html
          Response body (2417 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML>
<html>
	<head>
		<title>VulnerableBlog9000</title>
		<meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" />
		<meta name="description" content="" />
		<meta name="keywords" content="" />
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><script src="css/ie/html5shiv.js"></script><![endif]-->
		<script src="js/jquery.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/skel-layers.min.js"></script>
		<script src="js/init.js"></script>
		<noscript>
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/skel.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-desktop.css" />
			<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style-wide.css" />
		</noscript>
		<!--[if lte IE 8]><link rel="stylesheet" href="css/ie/v8.css" /><![endif]-->
	</head>
	<!--
		Note: Set the body element's class to "left-sidebar" to position the sidebar on the left.
		Set it to "right-sidebar" to, you guessed it, position it on the right.
	-->
	<body class="left-sidebar">

		<!-- Wrapper -->
			<div id="wrapper">

				<!-- Content -->
					<div id="content">
						<div class="inner">
                            <div style="width:20%;">
        <form method="get" name="login">
        <label>Meno</label>
        <input name="name" value="" type="text" placeholder="LamaCoder" autofocus />
        <label>Heslo</label>
        <input name="pass" value="" type="password" placeholder="********" />
        <br />
        <button class="button" name="logIN" value="1">Prihlasi</button>
    </form>
</div>
						</div>
					</div>

				<!-- Sidebar -->
					<div id="sidebar">
					
						<!-- Logo -->
							<h1 id="logo"><a href="#">LameBlog</a></h1>
					
						<!-- Nav -->
							<nav id="nav">
								<ul>
									<li class="current"><a href="./?page=">lnky</a></li>
                                    <li><a href="./?page=kontakt.php">Kontakt</a></li>
                                    <li><a href="./?page=login.php">Login</a></li>								</ul>
							</nav>

						<!-- Search -->
							<section class="box search">
								<form method="post" action="index.php?page=search.php">
									<input type="text" class="text" name="search" placeholder="Search" />
								</form>
							</section>

						<!-- Copyright -->
							<ul id="copyright">
							</ul>
					</div>
			</div>
	</body>
</html>
          Evidence 
          X-Powered-By: PHP/5.4.39-0+deb7u2
          Solution

          Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to suppress "X-Powered-By" headers.
        2. GET http://192.168.56.102/udpb/www-vulnerable/?name=ZAP&page=kontakt.php&pass=ZAP

          • OWASP_2017_A03

</html>
          Evidence 
          X-Powered-By: PHP/5.4.39-0+deb7u2
          Solution

          Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to suppress "X-Powered-By" headers.

          Evidence
